title: Gabriel Sundukian
text:
Gabriel Sundukian (; 11 July 1825 – 29 March 1912) was an <a href="Armenia">Armenia</a>n writer and playwright, the founder of modern Armenian drama.
Biography.
Born in <a href="Tiflis">Tiflis</a>, in a wealthy Armenian family, Sundukian learned both classical and modern Armenian, French, Italian and Russian, studied at the <a href="Saint%20Petersburg%20State%20University">University of Saint-Petersburg</a>, where he wrote a dissertation on the principles of Persian versification. Then he returned to Tiflis and entered the civil service. In 1854–58 he was banished to <a href="Derbend">Derbend</a> (<a href="Dagestan">Dagestan</a>, <a href="Russia">Russia</a>). In 1863, the Armenian theatre company of Tiflis staged his first play, "Sneezing at Night's Good Luck". His well-known play "Pepo" (1871) was made into the first Armenian talkie in 1935. Another famous film based on his work is "Khatabala" (1971). The <a href="Sundukyan%20State%20Academic%20Theatre%20of%20Yerevan">G. Sundukyan State Academic Theatre</a> in Yerevan is named in his honor.
